Listing goal: Aggregate zone
Notes: Single lookup that contains results from black, exploit and policy lists.

Listing goal: Lists individual IP addresses that have sent mail to spam traps.  And some manual added netblocks.
Nomination: Mostly Automatic with some manual additions.
Listing lifetime: For automated listings 5.6 days after last event, manual additions are permanent.

Listing goal: Lists IP addresses behaving in a way that indicates the IP is compromised, infected, proxy, VPN, TOR, malware,
Lists IP addresses that should not be connecting directly to MX, such as residential IPs etc.
Notes: Lists ranges that have generic or templated rDNS.  Individual IPs can be delisted immediately via web.

Listing goal: Lists domains seen in spam hitting traps.
Notes: Can be used as an RHSBL and a URIBL.

Listing goal: Lists domains that are newly observed (first use)
Notes: Based on historical passive DNS data, lists domains first seen in the wild within the last 25 hours).

Listing goal: Lists short URLs (SHA-1 hashed) seen in traps.
Notes: Created to handle popular shorteners that are misused to hide domains from blacklisting.

Listing goal: Lists URLs of online drive services (SHA-1 hashed) seen in traps.
Notes: Current only listing Google Drive and Yandex Disk URLs that are used to avoid domain blacklisting.

Listing goal: Extremely conservative list of single IP4 addresses that produce exclusively spam/malware as indicated by the GBUdb IP Reputation system. Most systems should be able to safely reject connections based on this list.
Nomination: Automatic: IPs are added when the GBUdb "cloud" statistics reach a probability figure that indicates 95% of messages produce a spam/malware pattern match and a confidence figure that indicates sufficient data to trust the probability data.
Listing lifetime: Automatic: Continuous while reputation statistics remain bad. Warning: Produces false positives, and has no remedy/removal process. IPs are dropped quickly if the statistics improve (within an hour). IPs are dropped within 36 hours (typ) if no more messages are seen (dead zombie).
Notes:
Source data is derived from a global network of Message Sniffer[1] filtering nodes in real-time. Truncate data is updated from statistics every 10 minutes.
Warning: Unreliable, as it produces false positives. It is impossible to find additional information or to manually troubleshoot the problem. It is based on results created by their proprietary software running a proprietary algorithm.

Listing goal: Single IP addresses which only send UBE. Specializing in snowshoe spam and other 'under the radar' spams which evade many other DNSBLs. Has FP-level comparable to Zen.
Nomination: Automatic (upon receipt of a spam to a real person's mailbox), with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
Listing lifetime: Typically an automatic expiration 11 days after the last abuse was seen, but with some exceptions
Notes: Spam samples are always kept on file for each listing. Removal requests are manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: Lists /24 blocks of IP addresses which usually only send UBE and containing at least several addresses which are confirmed emitters of junk mail. Collateral listings are kept to a minimum because subsections are often carved from /24 listings when spammers and legit senders share the same /24 block.
Nomination: Automatic once at least several IP addresses from a given block are individually listed on ivmSIP, with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
Listing lifetime: Expiration time increases to many weeks as the fraction of IP addresses in the /24 block in question sending junk mail increases
Notes: Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: Comparable to uribl.com and surbl.org, this is a list of IP addresses and domains which are used by spammers in the clickable links found in the body of spam messages
Nomination: Automatic (upon receipt of a spam to a real person's mailbox), with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
Listing lifetime: Typically an automatic expiration several weeks after the last abuse was seen.
Notes: Spam samples are always kept on file for each listing. Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: Single IP addresses that send mail to spamtraps
Nomination: Automatic by a cluster of more than 60 trapservers [3]
Listing lifetime: Automatic expiration 7 days after the last abuse was seen, optionally express delisting for a small fee.
Notes: UCEPROTECT's primary and the only independent list

Listing goal: Allocations with exceeded UCEPROTECT Level 1 listings
Listing lifetime: Automatic removal as soon as Level 1 listings decrease below Level 2 listing border, optionally express delisting (for a fee)
Notes: Fully depending on Level 1

Listing goal: ASN's with excessive UCEPROTECT Level 1 listings
Listing lifetime: Automatic removal as soon as Level 1 listings decrease below Level 3 listing border, optionally express delisting (fee)
Notes: Fully depending on Level 1

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Unsolicited bulk/commercial email senders
Notes: Aggregate zone (all aggregates and what they include are listed on SORBS)[4]

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Unsolicited bulk/commercial email senders
Notes: "Safe" Aggregate zone (all zones in dnsbl.sorbs.net except "recent", "old", "spam" and "escalations")

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Open HTTP proxy servers

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Open SOCKS proxy servers

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Additional proxy servers
Notes: Those not already listed in the HTTP or SOCKS databases

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Open SMTP relay servers

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: IP addresses with vulnerabilities that are exploitable by spammers (e.g. FormMail scripts)
Listing lifetime: Until delisting requested or Automated Expiry

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Hosts that have sent spam to the admins of SORBS or SORBS Spamtraps in the last 48 hours
Listing lifetime: Renewed every 20 minutes based inclusion in on 'spam.dnsbl.sorbs.net'

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Hosts that have sent spam to the admins of SORBS or SORBS Spamtraps in the last 28 days
Listing lifetime: Renewed every 20 minutes based inclusion in on 'spam.dnsbl.sorbs.net'

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Hosts that have sent spam to the admins of SORBS or SORBS Spamtraps in the last year
Listing lifetime: Renewed every 20 minutes based inclusion in on 'spam.dnsbl.sorbs.net'

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Hosts that have allegedly sent spam to the admins of SORBS or SORBS Spamtraps at any time

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Netblocks of service providers believed to support spammers
Listing lifetime: Until delisting requested and matter resolved.
Notes: Service providers are added on receipt of a 'third strike' spam

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Hosts demanding that they never be tested

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Hijacked networks

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Dynamic IP address ranges
Notes: Not a list of dial-up IP addresses

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: No Servers Permitted by ISP Policy
Notes: No Servers Permitted by ISP Policy

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Aggregate RHS zones

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Domains with invalid A or MX records in DNS
Nomination: Open submission via automated testing page.

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing goal: Domains which the owners have confirmed will not be used for sending email
This list contains IP addresses that are observed to be involved in sending spam, snowshoe spamming, botnet command and controllers (C&Cs), bulletproof hosting companies and hijacked IP space.
Listing lifetime: From five minutes to a year or more, depending on issue and resolution

Listing goal: This lists the individual IPs (/32s) that are infected with malware, worms, and Trojans; third party exploits, such as open proxies; or devices controlled by botnets. The constantly updated list is designed to protect networks from malware and spam by preventing mailservers  from accepting connections from compromised computing devices.
Listing lifetime: Varies, under a month, self removal via Composite Blocking List lookup.
Notes: Consists of the Composite Blocking List

Listing goal: This list is a real-time database of raw and filtered feeds that provides additional information on hijacked IP addresses. The eXBL is available to selected security organizations and cyber incident response teams.
Listing lifetime: Varies, under a month, self removal via Composite Blocking List lookup.
Notes: Consists of the Composite Blocking List

Listing goal: Domains owned by spammers and used for spam or other malicious purposes. This blocklist also contains domains owned by non-spammers which are used for legitimate purposes, but have been hijacked by spammers.
Nomination: Ranking of over 80 different metrics and machine learning
Listing lifetime: A few days. Self-removal  generally allowed.

Listing goal:
This list provides detailed information on each domain listing and is available via an API. This enables you to query the DBL engine, returning a JSON record for each domain that you are investigating.
The Enhanced Domain Blocklist (eDBL) helps you to track a particular domain's score over a longer period, or combine Domain Blocklist data with information from your own threat intelligence platform.
Listing lifetime: A few days. Self-removal  generally allowed.

Listing goal: This list includes IP address ranges for end-user devices, such as home routers, smart TVs, and other Information of Things (IoT) devices, from which email should never be sent.  This protects networks from the potential of being compromised by malware spread by botnet command and controller servers (C&Cs).
Nomination: Manual, by providers controlling the IPs or by Spamhaus PBL Team
Notes: Should not be confused with the MAPS DUL and Wirehub Dynablocker lists

Listing goal:
This list contains the following content areas: Cryptowallet (Bitcoin etc.), Malware and Email addresses.
Hash Blocklists (HBL) are lists of cryptographic hashes associated with malicious content, as opposed to IP addresses or domains. They are extremely useful for filtering fraudulent emails coming from ISPs, domains, or IP addresses that Spamhaus is unable to list e.g. Gmail. Additionally, they can block emails containing malware files.
Nomination: Manual, by providers controlling the IPs or by Spamhaus PBL Team

Listing goal:
This lists newly registered domains for 24 hours. Domains that have just been registered are rarely used by legitimate organizations immediately. Cybercriminals register and burn 100s of domains daily.
The Zero Reputation Domain (ZRD) blocklist helps to protect your users from clicking on links and visiting newly registered domains until it is established that they are not associated with zero day attacks; phishing, bot-herding, spyware and ransomware campaigns.
A single lookup for querying the SBL, XBL and PBL databases.
Notes: Preferred list to check all Spamhaus listings with one query.
This DNSBL zone is part of the default configuration for Proventia Mail Security System and Lotus Protector for Mail Security

Listing goal: IP addresses used to send spam to trap
IP addresses used to send spam to trap
IP addresses used to send UBE to members
IP addresses which have been used to transmit reported email to SpamCop users
Listing lifetime: Temporary, until spam stops, has self removal

Listing goal: IP addresses detected as abusive at ISP's using MagicMail Servers, with no reverse DNS service
Listing lifetime: Listed until removed, and reverse DNS configured

Listing goal: IP addresses detected as abusive at ISP's using MagicMail Servers, with non-conforming reverse DNS service (See Best Practises) indicative of compromised systems
Listing lifetime: Listed until removed, and reverse DNS set to conform to Best Practises

Listing goal: IP addresses detected as abusive at ISP's using MagicMail Servers, and manually confirmed as spam sources
IP addresses detected probing passwords or authenticating without sending mail
Detects viruses by behavior using fake high MX and tracking non-use of QUIT
Listing lifetime: Black list Data lives for 4 days. White list data lives for 10 days.

Blacklist operator: Heise Zeitschriften Verlag GmbH & Co. KG, hosted by manitu GmbH
Listing goal: Lists single IPs (no IP ranges) that send spam to spamtraps. Lists mailhosts, rather than domains, and thus blocks entire hosting providers and ISPs.
Nomination: Automated listing due to spamtrap hits. Exceptions apply to bounces, NDRs and whitelisted IPs.
Listing lifetime: 12 hours after last listing or until self delisting
Notes: TXT records provide information of listing incident - NiX Spam also provides hashes for fuzzy checksum plugin (iXhash) for SpamAssassin.

Listing goal: IP-Addresses who Attacks other Server/Honeypots over ssh, imap, smtp, ftp, web, rfi, sqli, ddos....
Nomination: Automatic: over Honeypots and with over 515 Users and 630 Servers from blocklist.de via Fail2Ban or own scripts
Listing lifetime: Automatic: 48 Hours after the last Attack. But earlier remove is available over the Delist-Link
Notes: Services are free. Source data is from Honeypot-Systems and over 515 User with 630 Servern there reports Attacks with Fail2Ban

Listing goal: Spam sources from email, forums, referrer spam and dictionary attacks
Listing lifetime: Twelve months unless ISPs request removal earlier
Notes: By request. ISPs can provide request exclusion.

Listing goal: Spam Trap
Nomination: List of IP addresses that sends spam or causing troubles with botnets or phishing
Notes: Removal requests will be investigated and processed within 24 hours of submission. Previously known as IPrange.net RBL Project

Listing goal: Collection of Bad Actors from various sources, Works great with PiHole for personal use.
Nomination: Spammers, Scammers, Malware, Cryptominers, TOR, botnets, phishing, attackers, harvesters, exfiltration etc. Basically anything and everything "bad"
Notes: Removal requests will be investigated. Contact details provided.

Listing goal: Spam Trap
Nomination: Provides a list of IP addresses which are sending spam. The Barracuda Reputation system uses automated collection methods to add and delete IP addresses from the BRBL.
Notes: Requires registration of administrator and hosts to use. Removal requests are typically investigated and processed within 12 hours of submission if provided with a valid explanation.

Listing goal: Bad reputation, difficult to identify the responsible, dynamic IP, SLAAC flag without genuine email service and inappropriate use of the URL
Nomination: Provides a list of IPv4/IPv6 addresses and domains which are sending spam or phishing.
Listing lifetime: Until delisting requested or seven days with good reputation.
Notes: The feedback system runs at SMTP layer. See https://spfbl.net/en/feedback

Listing goal: IP addresses which have sent email to addresses harvested from suppression (opt-out) files
Listing lifetime: For 30 days after last offending message unless removal is requested

Listing goal: IP addresses detected as unsolicited bulk/commercial email senders, webspam
Notes: Removal requests are manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: Unsolicited bulk/commercial email senders, webspam
Notes: Removal requests are manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: Spam Traps
Nomination: A single IP(127.0.0.#) is listed upon sending spam to a spam trap, sending from multiple IPs within a range within a short period of time will result in a class C listing(127.0.#.0).
Listing lifetime: Until an IP owner/authorized admin requests listing removal.
Notes:
Single IP Listed with Data result 127.0.0.#
Class C IP Block Listed with Data result 127.0.#.0
Codes are as follows: (ie. General spam single IP result 127.0.0.1) 

general spam, Sending spam to our spam traps.
Removal request made but missing required information, please make a new request and be sure to complete the form properly.
Does not follow valid can-spam rules for newsletters / lists.
Not RFC compliant, server errors or improper configuration.
Repeat offenders, these are IP's that have been removed and listed again (3) or more times in a short period of time.
Bouncing email to the wrong server, RFC-non-compliant configurations.
Relay or Open relay with reports of spam.
bouncing spoofed emails, you need to disable bounce of spoofed emails in order to get de listed.
Fraud/Scam emails, malware or illegal/abusive content.

Listing goal: IPs and domains for junk mail filtering (aggregate zone).
Nomination: Mostly automatic with some manual additions.
